title: 104_hr2635
content: The "Fair Elections Act" aims to address existing problems in Federal election laws in a nonpartisan manner, considering constitutional freedoms of speech and association. It acknowledges bias favoring incumbent Members of Congress and the need for reform. The "Fair Elections Commission" is established to study and recommend legislation to reform laws relating to elections for Congress. The Fair Elections Commission, composed of 12 members appointed by the President with Senate approval, includes individuals not currently in Congress and with specific qualifications. Consultation with House and Senate leaders is required for the appointment of members. The Fair Elections Commission consists of 12 members appointed by the President with Senate approval. The minority leaders of the House and Senate appoint 2 members each, one of whom is not affiliated with the Republican or Democratic Party. The Chairman of the Commission cannot be affiliated with either major party. Members serve for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and no more than 4 members can be from the same political party. The Fair Elections Commission, consisting of 12 members appointed by the President with Senate approval, has the power to hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence as needed. A quorum of seven members is required, with a majority needed for approving recommended legislation. Any member can take authorized actions on behalf of the Commission. The Fair Elections Commission, appointed by the President with Senate approval, must submit a report to Congress within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The report will include recommended legislation to reform the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 and other election-related laws. The Commission's primary objectives are outlined in Section 7. The Fair Elections Commission's primary objectives, as outlined in Section 7, include promoting fair and open Congressional elections, reducing special interest influence, and leveling the playing field for incumbent Members of Congress and challengers. The section enacted by Congress outlines rules for the House of Representatives and Senate, recognizing their right to change rules. It defines a "Federal election bill" as a bill introduced in Congress to carry out specific provisions. Within 3 days of the Commission submitting its draft legislation, a Federal election bill must be introduced in the House and Senate by the majority leaders. No amendments are allowed to the bill, and there is a set period for committee and floor consideration. The Federal election bill must be introduced within 3 days of the Commission submitting its draft legislation by the majority leaders. If the committee has not reported the bill by the 20th day after its introduction, it will be automatically discharged and placed on the calendar for consideration. If both Houses pass a Federal election bill, the final vote will be on the bill from the other House. In computing a number of days in either House, days on which the House is not in session due to adjournment of more than 3 days or adjournment of Congress sine die are excluded. In the House of Representatives, a motion to proceed to consider a Federal election bill is highly privileged and can only be made on the second legislative day after announcement, not debatable, and not subject to amendment or reconsideration. Floor consideration of a Federal election bill in the House of Representatives is limited to 10 hours, divided equally between supporters and opponents. Appeals on House rules related to the bill are decided without debate. In the Senate, a motion to proceed to consideration is allowed. In the Senate, a motion to proceed to consider a Federal election bill is privileged and not debatable. Debate on the bill is limited to 10 hours, divided between majority and minority leaders. Debate on any motion or appeal related to the bill is limited to 1 hour. In the Senate, the time for debate on a Federal election bill is controlled by the mover and manager of the bill. The minority leader can control the time in opposition if the manager is in favor of a motion. Additional time can be allotted by the leaders during consideration of any debatable motion. A motion to further limit debate is not debatable, and a motion to recommit the bill is not allowed. SEC. 9. ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS. Members of the Commission are paid based on their level, with the Chairman receiving a higher rate. They also receive travel expenses as per regulations. The Commission appoints a staff director independently. The Commission appoints a staff director who is paid at the rate of level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Director can appoint additional personnel without following the usual appointment procedures and pay regulations, with a salary limit of grade GS-15 of the General Schedule. The Commission may detail personnel from federal departments to assist in its duties. It can also hire experts or consultants on a temporary basis. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting its report. Appropriations are authorized for the Commission's duties under this Act.
